Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Breakthrough: Design of Network Dynamics for Strategic Team-Competition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Over the past decade there has been a growing awareness and interest in large networked systems such as those presented by power (smart-grid), communication, biological, social and sensor networks. A large body of research focused on networked systems has resulted where the primary goal has been the design of strategies by which individual agents in a network cooperate to achieve coordinated goals. Less studied are competitive-strategic scenarios where agents may be competing while trying to achieve their objectives, or may be competing in teams using local communications for local coordination purposes. This project considers the competitive-strategic domain for two opposing teams, motivated by applications that can abstractly be viewed as a competition between a large collection of autonomous agents, and an adversarial agent or team of adversaries. A primary example is the problem of controlling a large wind farm composed of numerous turbines: each rotating blade creates a downstream wake and every turbine faces the problem of setting an appropriate rotation speed under complex aerodynamic interactions. The cooperative control problem is to determine rotation speeds for the individual turbines that maximize the total collective energy extracted from the wind, under wake effects from neighboring turbines and difficult-to-predict variations in wind speeds and directions. In this example, the Principal Investigators propose to address a generalization of the problem where the turbines are viewed as competing against nature, which continually and adversarial changes the wind speed at each turbine. Ongoing with the analytical and applications-oriented research efforts will be the development of educational programs with interdisciplinary activities in optimization, mathematical systems theory, game theory and clustering algorithms. Both graduate and undergraduate students will be involved, with an emphasis on attracting students from underrepresented groups to participate in the research activities throughout the duration of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has been focused on the development of an optimization framework and associated analysis for dynamic interactions between multiple agents connected via a network. We have used control-theoretic analyses, distributed gradient approaches, and network inference and information-theoretic methods to attain our main outcomes bearing intellectual merit; these include:

  • modeling and convergence analysis of single and multiple spread processes (e.g., viruses) evolving over networks, including competitive and cooperative scenarios;
  • distributed localization and distributed learning algorithms in multi-agen systems, e.g., where each agent can measure noisy distances to a target.  When the distance from one agent to a target is known, one can localize the target to a circle, however if one  
    knows the distance and the noise, one can localize it to a smaller annulus. If there are many agents all measuring distance and noise this allows for efficient localization, for example using a distributed optimization method inspired by a generalization of Bayes' rule;
  • distributed optimization algorithms and associated convergence analysis under communication delays, including deriving upper bounds on the rate of convergence of distributed subgradient algorithms as a function of network size, topology, and inter-processor communication delays, without necessitating any topology modifications;
  • development and analysis of distributed Lagrangian optimization approaches;
  • convergence analysis of the iterate values in mirror descent algorithms;
  • development of distributed algorithms and consistency analysis, as well as nonasymptotic, explicit, and geometric convergence rates, for the concentration of beliefs around a set of optimal hypotheses for distributed learning problems;
  • fast and accurate graph partitioning algorithms.

We have further contributed to the modeling, optimization and control of applied engineering problems associated with the broader impacts of the project.  Examples of this include:

  • modeling and development of control-based approaches for maximizing power extraction from wind farm arrays under varying wind conditions, explicitly accounting for dynamic coupling between wind turbines;
  • application of our distributed Lagrangian algorithms to solve deterministic tie-line scheduling problems in the power grid, as well as robust variants (e.g., with policy space approximations), for which we do not require any form of central coordination; 
  • modeling and analysis of virus spread over time-varying contact networks, including the relaxation of existing sufficient conditions for convergence to the healthy state;

Additionally, training and supervision during the project has included 1 postdoc, 5 PhD students, 1 Master's student, and 1 undergraduate student, all of whom have been active in the research described herein, with three of these students from historically underrepresented groups.


Last Modified: 07/16/2019
Modified by: Carolyn L Beck
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project has been focused on the development of an optimization framework and associated analysis for dynamic interactions between multiple agents connected via a network. We have used control-theoretic analyses, distributed gradient approaches, and network inference and information-theoretic methods to attain our main outcomes bearing intellectual merit; these include: modeling and convergence analysis of single and multiple spread processes (e.g., viruses) evolving over networks, including competitive and cooperative scenarios; distributed localization and distributed learning algorithms in multi-agen systems, e.g., where each agent can measure noisy distances to a target. When the distance from one agent to a target is known, one can localize the target to a circle, however if one knows the distance and the noise, one can localize it to a smaller annulus. If there are many agents all measuring distance and noise this allows for efficient localization, for example using a distributed optimization method inspired by a generalization of Bayes' rule; distributed optimization algorithms and associated convergence analysis under communication delays, including deriving upper bounds on the rate of convergence of distributed subgradient algorithms as a function of network size, topology, and inter-processor communication delays, without necessitating any topology modifications; development and analysis of distributed Lagrangian optimization approaches; convergence analysis of the iterate values in mirror descent algorithms; development of distributed algorithms and consistency analysis, as well as nonasymptotic, explicit, and geometric convergence rates, for the concentration of beliefs around a set of optimal hypotheses for distributed learning problems; fast and accurate graph partitioning algorithms. We have further contributed to the modeling, optimization and control of applied engineering problems associated with the broader impacts of the project. Examples of this include: modeling and development of control-based approaches for maximizing power extraction from wind farm arrays under varying wind conditions, explicitly accounting for dynamic coupling between wind turbines; application of our distributed Lagrangian algorithms to solve deterministic tie-line scheduling problems in the power grid, as well as robust variants (e.g., with policy space approximations), for which we do not require any form of central coordination; modeling and analysis of virus spread over time-varying contact networks, including the relaxation of existing sufficient conditions for convergence to the healthy state; Additionally, training and supervision during the project has included 1 postdoc, 5 PhD students, 1 Master's student, and 1 undergraduate student, all of whom have been active in the research described herein, with three of these students from historically underrepresented groups.
